title: 111_hr1861
content: The Act may be cited as the "Daniel Pearl Freedom of the Press Act of 2009". Congress finds that acts of violence against journalists and media personnel are increasing, with very few resulting in prosecution. In 2008, 41 journalists were killed and 125 imprisoned. Internet reporting is on the rise, leading to the imprisonment of online editors and bloggers. The safety and independence of journalists are a pressing international concern. The United Nations General Assembly adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948, which includes Article 19 stating the right to freedom of opinion and expression. The purposes of the Act are to promote the work of journalists advocating for freedom of expression, raise awareness of threats faced by journalists worldwide, and provide protection to them and media organizations. The United Nations General Assembly adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948, emphasizing the right to freedom of opinion and expression. The Act aims to promote the work of journalists advocating for freedom of expression and raise awareness of threats faced by journalists worldwide. Additionally, it seeks to provide protection to journalists and media organizations. The Act also highlights the importance of including freedom of the press in United States foreign policy. SEC. 3. ANNUAL REPORT ON THE PROMOTION OF FREEDOM OF THE PRESS WORLDWIDE. The Secretary of State is required to submit an annual report to Congress on the promotion of freedom of the press worldwide. The report, titled "Annual Report on the Status of Freedom of the Press Worldwide," will be prepared with the assistance of the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor and will include information on the status of press freedom in each country, initiatives supporting press freedom, and violations of press freedom in certain countries. The annual report on freedom of the press worldwide will address violations such as physical attacks, imprisonment, censorship by various groups. It will also evaluate government participation in these violations and measures taken to protect journalists. The Annual Report on freedom of the press worldwide is organized into three parts, identifying countries and assessing their efforts. It is submitted on May 3 each year in unclassified form. The Secretary of State administers a grant program to promote global press freedom, managed by the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor. Grants range from $70,000 to $150,000 annually for up to five years. Proposals aim to enhance journalist independence, legal frameworks, and media skills in traditional and digital platforms. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Secretary of State for $2,000,000 annually from 2010 to 2014 to implement the Act. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, including "Annual Report" as the report on the Status of Freedom of the Press Worldwide, "media organization" as a group disseminating news in a foreign country, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of State.
